trial_identification.studytitle: A New Surgical Incision Method To Improving Post Operative Scars in Patients.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The Deckled Incision: A new surgical approach to improving post-operative scars.

interventions.interventions: The "Deckled" incision is new approach to the scalpel incision. It involves making a curvilinear incision and utilises W-plasty principles to lead to improve scars.

primaryOutcome.outcome: To assess clinician opinion of scar quality using Observer component of scar scale
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 1 week post op 3 months post op 6 months post op

primaryOutcome.outcome: To assess the patients opinion of scar quality/sensation using the Patient component of the scar scale
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 1 week post op 3 months post op 6 months post op

secondaryOutcome.outcome: The proportion of scars assessed as good by the clinician (determined by less than or equal to 5 on the Overall component of the POSAS)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: 1 week post op 3 Months post op 6 Months post op

secondaryOutcome.outcome: The proportion of scar assessed as good by the patients (determined by less than or equal to 5 on the Overall component of the POSAS)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: 1 week post op 3 Months post op 6 months post op

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Number of adverse events overall and by individual components (namely dehiscence infection, keloids). These will be assessed at the outpatient clinics and from review of relevant medical records
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: 1 week post op 3 months post op 6 months post op

secondaryOutcome.outcome: The percentage of the scar visible as a percentage of the total length of the scar at 1 meter"
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: 1 week post op 3 months post op 6 months post op

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1 Age range: Greater than or equal to 18 years of age. 2 Able to give informed consent and willingness to participate in follow up. 3 Undergoing any plastic surgery procedure involving excision of skin lesions
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1 Those requiring re-excision through the original wound 2 Undergoing injectable corticosteroid therapy into the scar

trial_design.concealment: External person will notify surgeon via phone which lesions will be "Deckled" or have straight line incision. Because lesions are randomised rather than the patient, an individual patient may undergo both excision with both 'deckled' and straight line incisions.
trial_design.statisticalmethods: Independent two-sample T test, Chi-squared and Logistic Regression Analysis . A difference of 1 on the overall scar scale was deemed to be statistically significant however this may not be clinically significant. A 10% difference in the secondary analysis looking at the proportion of good overall scars was subsequently used to assess clinical significance. We anticipate a 10% attrition rate. No formal sample size calculation was performed.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study aims to evaluate if whether using the Deckled incision improves post-operative scars compared to the standard straight line incision in people undergoing surgery for skin lesions. Who is it for? You may be eligible to join this study if you are aged 18 years or more and are scheduled to undergo any plastic surgery procedure involving excision of skin lesions. Study details Participants in this study will be randomly allocated (by chance) to one of two groups in an equal ratio. Participants will not be aware of the group/treatment they have been allocated to receive. For patients with multiple lesions, because each lesion is randomised, they may have both the "Deckled" incision or straight line incision performed. This study will help determine if Deckled incision has superior scar outcomes compared to the straight line incision approach.
